For all to enjoy - the first link includes explanations of the underutilized housing tax (UHT), the second link is to the form:https://www.canada.ca/en/services/ta...using-tax.htmlhttps://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-age.../uht-2900.html

Hello All, For those of you who are US-based, but own property in Canada, you may find this information useful. Kudos to Northwoods Realty Ltd. for sending out this information to customers. The Underused Housing Tax Act levies a 1% annual tax on foreign owners of residential property in Canada that has remained vacant for more than half of the year. While the definition of residential is broad, all rural properties, including those in Sioux Narrows, Nestor Falls and Morson, are excluded from the requirement of having to pay this tax, provided you have stayed at the property for at least 28 days during the previous year. There are further exemptions for properties that are not suitable for year-round use as a place of residence, and properties that are only seasonally accessible. Disappointingly, the federal government still requires that non-residents file a return, confirming that they are exempt from paying this tax. The minimum penalty for failing to file a return is $5,000.00 per occurrence. This penalty applies even to those who are exempt from paying the tax. All non-resident owners, who owned property during the 2022 fiscal year, will be required to file a tax return by April 30, 2023, even if the ownership qualifies for an exemption. They will be required to file a return each following year confirming their exemption from the tax. To do so, they will be required to first request an Individual Tax Number from the Canada Revenue Agency (attached) and then complete the UHT-2900 form (also attached) It is recommend that you complete and submit the UHT-2900 in advance of the April 30 deadline to avoid any potential penalties.
